The Battle of Panchjanya is the debut novel of Indian author Subham Sahu, and the first book in the Krishna Trilogy. Released on 16 August 2025, it reimagines events from the early life of Krishna through an epic, action-driven narrative, blending history, mythology, and fiction. The novel follows Krishna’s journey from Sandipani Ashram to the ocean-bound kingdom of Panchjanya, ruled by the tyrant Shankhashur, culminating in a decisive battle that lays the foundation of Dwarka.
Plot synopsis
The novel opens with the Vasudev Committee, led by Maharishi Parshuram, debating the unstable state of the kingdoms and deciding to appoint a new Vasudev—a leader who will enforce new laws and restore balance in society. The task of finding a worthy candidate is entrusted to seven Maharishis.
Maharishi Vyas’s search leads him to Sandipani Ashram, where he encounters Krishna, a uniquely gifted child. Testing his capability, Vyas informs Krishna about Purandutta, a long-lost student of the ashram abducted by soldiers of the island kingdom of Panchjanya, ruled by the ruthless king Shankhashur. Determined to rescue Purandutta, Krishna sets out with Balaram, Sudama, and Subal, journeying to Prabhas and then to the Indian Ocean (Ratnakara), where the island lies.
The story follows Krishna’s rise from a student to a revolutionary, as he rallies the oppressed citizens of Panchjanya against Shankhashur. With Mahashivratri approaching, Krishna learns that Shankhashur is plotting something catastrophic that will make him invincible. Racing against time, Krishna faces formidable foes, including the eight elite warriors of Shankhashur, deadly Vishkanyas, shape-shifting Raktabizas, and the monstrous Kaalketu.
The climax unfolds in an intense oceanic battle between Krishna and Shankhashur, ending in the liberation of Panchjanya. The freed citizens proclaim Krishna as their king, marking the birth of the vision for Dwarka.
Returning to Sandipani Ashram, Krishna and Balaram take blessings from their gurus before accompanying Vyas to the Mahapariksha of Vasudev, where princes from across Aryavarta—including Arjun, Yudhishthir, Bheema, the Kauravas, Karna, Paundrak, and Shishupal—are to compete.
Interwoven into the main plot are Krishna’s personal memories with Radha, Yashoda, and Nand Baba, and the early lessons that shape his destiny.
The next book in the trilogy will focus on the Mahapariksha and the political intrigues surrounding it.
Development
According to the author, the concept for The Battle of Panchjanya was born from the desire to portray Krishna’s lesser-known youth adventures before the Mahabharata era. Blending mythological references with original characters, Subham Sahu envisioned a high-stakes mission that showcases Krishna’s leadership, strategy, and moral dilemmas.
